/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Creating rulesets for a repository
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: You can add rulesets to a repository to control how people can interact with specific branches and tags.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Managing rulesets for a repository
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: You can edit, monitor, and delete existing rulesets in a repository to alter how people can interact with specific branches and tags.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Available rules for rulesets
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: Learn which rules you can add to a ruleset to protect specific branches and tags in a repository.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Troubleshooting rules
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: Learn how to troubleshoot rulesets when you're contributing to a repository.

/en/repositories/working-with-files.title: Working with files
/en/repositories/working-with-files.intro: Learn how to manage and use files in repositories.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: Managing files
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: You can create, edit, move, and delete files in a repository, directly on GitHub or on the command line.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: Creating new files
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: You can create new files directly on GitHub in any repository you have write access to.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: Adding a file to a repository
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: You can upload and commit an existing file to a repository on GitHub or by using the command line.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: Moving a file to a new location
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: You can move a file to a different directory on GitHub or by using the command line.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: Editing files
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: You can edit files directly on GitHub in any of your repositories using the file editor.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: Renaming a file
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: You can rename any file in your repository directly in GitHub or by using the command line.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: Deleting files in a repository
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: You can delete an individual file or an entire directory in your repository on GitHub.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: Customizing how changed files appear on GitHub
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: To keep certain files from displaying in diffs by default, or counting toward the repository language, you can mark them with the linguist-generated attribute in a .gitattributes file.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/usin.title: Using files
/en/repositories/working-with-files/usin.intro: You can navigate and track changes in the code in your files.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/usin.title: Navigating code on GitHub
/en/repositories/working-with-files/usin.intro: You can understand the relationships within and across repositories by navigating code directly in GitHub.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/usin.title: Viewing a file
/en/repositories/working-with-files/usin.intro: You can view raw file content or trace changes to lines in a file and discover how parts of the file evolved over time.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/usin.title: Getting permanent links to files
/en/repositories/working-with-files/usin.intro: When viewing a file on GitHub.com, you can press the "y" key to update the URL to a permalink to the exact version of the file you see.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/usin.title: Downloading source code archives
/en/repositories/working-with-files/usin.intro: You can download a snapshot of the code in your repository.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/usin.title: Working with non-code files
/en/repositories/working-with-files/usin.intro: GitHub supports rendering and diffing in a number of non-code file formats.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: Managing large files
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: You can manage large files with Git Large File Storage.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: About large files on GitHub
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: GitHub limits the size of files you can track in regular Git repositories. Learn how to track or remove files that are beyond the limit.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: About Git Large File Storage
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: GitHub limits the size of files allowed in repositories. To track files beyond this limit, you can use Git Large File Storage.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: Installing Git Large File Storage
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: In order to use Git LFS, you'll need to download and install a new program that's separate from Git.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: Configuring Git Large File Storage
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: Once Git LFS is installed, you need to associate it with a large file in your repository.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: About storage and bandwidth usage
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: Every account using Git Large File Storage receives 1 GiB of free storage and 1 GiB a month of free bandwidth. If the bandwidth and storage quotas are not enough, you can choose to purchase an additional quota for Git LFS.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: Collaboration with Git Large File Storage
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: With Git LFS enabled, you'll be able to fetch, modify, and push large files just as you would expect with any file that Git manages. However, a user that doesn't have Git LFS will experience a different workflow.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: Moving a file in your repository to Git Large File Storage
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: If you've set up Git LFS, and you have an existing file in your repository that needs to be tracked in Git LFS, you need to first remove it from your repository.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: Removing files from Git Large File Storage
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: If you've set up Git LFS for your repository, you can remove all files or a subset of files from Git LFS.

/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.title: Resolving Git Large File Storage upload failures
/en/repositories/working-with-files/mana.intro: If your Git LFS files didn't upload properly, you can take several steps to troubleshoot the upload error.

/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.title: Releasing projects on GitHub
/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.intro: You can create a release to package software, release notes, and binary files for other people to download.

/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.title: About releases
/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.intro: You can create a release to package software, along with release notes and links to binary files, for other people to use.

/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.title: Managing releases in a repository
/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.intro: You can create releases to bundle and deliver iterations of a project to users.

/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.title: Viewing your repository's releases and tags
/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.intro: You can view the chronological history of your repository by release name or tag version number.

/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.title: Searching a repository's releases
/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.intro: You can use keywords, tags, and other qualifiers to search for particular releases in a repository.

/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.title: Linking to releases
/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.intro: You can share every release you create on GitHub with a unique URL.

/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.title: Comparing releases
/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.intro: You can compare release tags to see changes to your repository between different releases.

/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.title: Automatically generated release notes
/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.intro: You can automatically generate release notes for your GitHub releases

/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.title: Automation for release forms with query parameters
/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-g.intro: To quickly create releases by auto-populating the new release form with customized information, you can add query parameters to the URL for the release form page.

/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.title: Viewing activity and data for your repository
/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.intro: Gain insight into your repository by viewing activity and data.

/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.title: Viewing deployment activity for your repository
/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.intro: You can view information about deployments for your entire repository or a specific pull request.

/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.title: About repository graphs
/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.intro: Repository graphs help you view and analyze data for your repository.

/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.title: Using Pulse to view a summary of repository activity
/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.intro: You can use Pulse to see an overview of a repository's pull request, issue, and commit activity.

/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.title: Viewing traffic to a repository
/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.intro: Anyone with push access to a repository can view its traffic, including full clones (not fetches), visitors from the past 14 days, referring sites, and popular content in the traffic graph.

/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.title: Viewing a project's contributors
/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.intro: You can see who contributed commits to a repository and its dependencies.

/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.title: Analyzing changes to a repository's content
/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.intro: You can see the changes to the content of a repository by analyzing the repository's commits, commit frequency, and content additions and deletions.

/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.title: Understanding connections between repositories
/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.intro: Use the network graph and forks list to understand fork networks.

/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.title: Using the activity view to see changes to a repository
/en/repositories/viewing-activity-and-da.intro: You can use the activity view to see a detailed history of changes to your repository.

/en/repositories/archiving-a-github-repo.title: Archiving a GitHub repository
/en/repositories/archiving-a-github-repo.intro: You can archive, back up, and cite your work using GitHub, the API, or third-party tools and services.

/en/repositories/archiving-a-github-repo.title: Archiving repositories
/en/repositories/archiving-a-github-repo.intro: You can archive a repository to make it read-only for all users and indicate that it's no longer actively maintained. You can also unarchive repositories that have been archived.

/en/repositories/archiving-a-github-repo.title: About archiving content and data on GitHub
/en/repositories/archiving-a-github-repo.intro: You can archive content and data on GitHub for other people to view and reference.

/en/repositories/archiving-a-github-repo.title: Referencing and citing content
/en/repositories/archiving-a-github-repo.intro: You can use third-party tools to cite and reference content on GitHub.

/en/repositories/archiving-a-github-repo.title: Backing up a repository
/en/repositories/archiving-a-github-repo.intro: You can use Git, a third-party tool, or the API to back up your repository.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin.title: Enterprise administrator documentation
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin.intro: Documentation and guides for enterprise administrators and security specialists who configure and manage GitHub Enterprise Cloud.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/overvi.title: Overview
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/overvi.intro: You can learn about GitHub Enterprise Cloud and manage billing.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/overvi.title: About GitHub for enterprises
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/overvi.intro: Businesses can use GitHub's enterprise products to improve their entire software development lifecycle.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/overvi.title: About GitHub Enterprise Cloud
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/overvi.intro: GitHub Enterprise Cloud is designed for large businesses or teams who collaborate on GitHub.com.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/overvi.title: Setting up a trial of GitHub Enterprise Cloud
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/overvi.intro: You can try GitHub Enterprise Cloud for free.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/overvie.title: About GitHub Enterprise Server
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/overvie.intro: GitHub Enterprise Server is a software development platform that you can host in a private environment.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/overvi.title: Setting up a trial of GitHub Enterprise Server
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/overvi.intro: You can try GitHub Enterprise Server for free.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/overvie.title: About upgrades to new releases
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/overvie.intro: You can benefit from new features and bug fixes for GitHub Enterprise Server by upgrading your enterprise to a newly released version.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/overvi.title: About enterprise accounts
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/overvi.intro: With GitHub Enterprise Cloud, you can use an enterprise account to enable collaboration between your organizations, while giving administrators a single point of visibility and management.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/overvie.title: System overview
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/overvie.intro: Learn more about GitHub Enterprise Server's system internals, functionality, and security.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/overvie.title: About the GitHub Enterprise API
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/overvie.intro: GitHub Enterprise Server supports REST and GraphQL APIs.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/overvi.title: Best practices for enterprises
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/overvi.intro: Learn GitHub-recommended practices for your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/overvi.title: Accessing compliance reports for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/overvi.intro: You can access GitHub's compliance reports, such as our SOC reports and Cloud Security Alliance CAIQ self-assessment (CSA CAIQ), for your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Managing your enterprise account
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can use an enterprise account to centrally manage multiple organizations.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Creating an enterprise account
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: If you're currently using GitHub Enterprise Cloud with a single organization, you can create an enterprise account to centrally manage multiple organizations.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Deleting an enterprise account
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can delete an enterprise account to stop paying for GitHub Enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Changing the URL for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: If you want to change the URL where your enterprise is accessed, you can change your enterprise slug.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.title: Installing GitHub Enterprise
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.intro: System administrators and operations and security specialists can install GitHub Enterprise Server.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.title: Setting up a GitHub Enterprise Server instance
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.intro: You can install GitHub Enterprise Server on the supported virtualization platform of your choice.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.title: Installing GitHub Enterprise Server on AWS
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.intro: To install GitHub Enterprise Server on Amazon Web Services (AWS), you must launch an Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) instance and create and attach a separate Amazon Elastic Block Store (EBS) data volume.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.title: Installing GitHub Enterprise Server on Azure
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.intro: To install GitHub Enterprise Server on Azure, you must deploy onto a memory-optimized instance that supports premium storage.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.title: Installing GitHub Enterprise Server on Google Cloud Platform
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.intro: To install GitHub Enterprise Server on Google Cloud Platform, you must deploy onto a supported machine type and use a persistent standard disk or a persistent SSD.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.title: Installing GitHub Enterprise Server on Hyper-V
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.intro: To install GitHub Enterprise Server on Hyper-V, you must deploy onto a machine running Windows Server 2008 through Windows Server 2022.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.title: Installing GitHub Enterprise Server on OpenStack KVM
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.intro: To install GitHub Enterprise Server on OpenStack KVM, you must have OpenStack access and download the GitHub Enterprise Server QCOW2 image.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.title: Installing GitHub Enterprise Server on VMware
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.intro: To install GitHub Enterprise Server on VMware, you must download the VMware vSphere client, and then download and deploy the GitHub Enterprise Server software.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.title: Setting up a staging instance
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/install.intro: You can set up a GitHub Enterprise Server instance in a separate, isolated environment, and use the instance to validate and test changes.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.title: Configuring GitHub Enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.intro: You can configure your enterprise to suit your organization's needs.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.title: Configuring user applications for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.intro: You can configure applications for users in your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring applications
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can configure internal application settings for your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring email for notifications
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: To make it easy for users to respond quickly to activity on GitHub Enterprise Server, you can configure your GitHub Enterprise Server instance to send email notifications for issue, pull request, and commit comments.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring GitHub Pages for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can enable or disable GitHub Pages for your enterprise and choose whether to make sites publicly accessible.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring rate limits
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can set rate limits for GitHub Enterprise Server using the Management Console.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring web commit signing
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can enable auto-signing of commits made in the web interface of GitHub Enterprise Server.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring interactive maps
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can enable the display of interactive maps in the web interface for your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Managing GitHub Mobile for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can decide whether people can use GitHub Mobile to connect to your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.title: Verifying or approving a domain for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.intro: You can verify your ownership of domains with GitHub to confirm the identity of organizations owned by your enterprise account. You can also approve domains where organization members can receive email notifications.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.title: Hardening security for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.intro: You can configure features and settings to harden security for your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring TLS
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can configure Transport Layer Security (TLS) on your GitHub Enterprise Server instance so that you can use a certificate that is signed by a trusted certificate authority.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Troubleshooting TLS errors
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: If you run into TLS issues with your appliance, you can take actions to resolve them.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Enabling private mode
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: In private mode, GitHub Enterprise Server requires every user to sign in to access the installation.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Enabling subdomain isolation
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can set up subdomain isolation to securely separate user-supplied content from other portions of your GitHub Enterprise Server appliance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring host keys for your instance
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can increase the security of your GitHub Enterprise Server instance by configuring the algorithms that your instance uses to generate and advertise host keys for incoming SSH connections.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring SSH connections to your instance
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can increase the security of your GitHub Enterprise Server instance by configuring the SSH algorithms that clients can use to establish a connection.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring the referrer policy for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can increase the privacy of your GitHub Enterprise Server instance by configuring the policy for cross-origin requests.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.title: Restricting network traffic to your enterprise with an IP allow list
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.intro: You can restrict access to your enterprise and only allow access to your resources from specified IP addresses by using an IP allow list.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring network settings
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: Configure GitHub Enterprise Server with the DNS nameservers and hostname required in your network. You can also configure a proxy server or firewall rules. You must allow access to certain ports for administrative and user purposes.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring the IP address using the virtual machine console
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: By default, GitHub Enterprise Server retrieves network settings via the dynamic host configuration protocol (DHCP). If your platform supports it, or if DHCP is unavailable, you can also configure the network settings using the virtual machine console.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring DNS nameservers
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: GitHub Enterprise Server uses the dynamic host configuration protocol (DHCP) for DNS settings when DHCP leases provide nameservers. If nameservers are not provided by a dynamic host configuration protocol (DHCP) lease, or if you need to use specific DNS settings, you can specify the nameservers manually.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring the hostname for your instance
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can provide reliable access to your GitHub Enterprise Server instance by assigning a hostname that's accessible over your network.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Changing the hostname for your instance
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: If you want to change the hostname for an existing GitHub Enterprise Server instance, you must restore the settings and data to a new instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Validating your domain settings
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: Ensure that your domain settings are properly configured before booting up your GitHub Enterprise Server instance for the first time.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring an outbound web proxy server
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: A proxy server provides an additional level of security for your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring built-in firewall rules
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can view default firewall rules and customize rules for your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Network ports
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: Open network ports selectively based on the network services you need to expose for administrators, end users, and email support.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Using GitHub Enterprise Server with a load balancer
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: Use a load balancer in front of a single GitHub Enterprise Server instance or a pair of instances in a High Availability configuration.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring time synchronization
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: GitHub Enterprise Server automatically synchronizes its clock by connecting to NTP servers. You can set the NTP servers that are used to synchronize the clock, or you can use the default NTP servers.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.title: Configuring private networking for hosted compute products
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.intro: You can configure private networking for GitHub-hosted products with network configurations

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.title: About networking for hosted compute products
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.intro: You can manage private networking for GitHub-hosted products using network configurations.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.title: About using GitHub-hosted runners in your Azure Virtual Network
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.intro: You can create GitHub-hosted runners in your Azure Virtual Network(s) (VNET).

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.title: Configuring private networking for GitHub-hosted runners
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/config.intro: Learn how to use GitHub-hosted runners with an Azure private network.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Configuring GitHub Connect
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: With GitHub Connect, you can access additional features and workflows by connecting your GitHub Enterprise Server instance to GitHub Enterprise Cloud.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: About GitHub Connect
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: GitHub Connect enhances GitHub Enterprise Server by giving you access to additional features and workflows that rely on the power of GitHub.com.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Managing GitHub Connect
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can enable GitHub Connect to access additional features and workflows for your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Enabling automatic user license sync for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can manage license usage across your GitHub Enterprise environments by automatically syncing user licenses from your GitHub Enterprise Server instance to GitHub Enterprise Cloud.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Enabling Dependabot for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can allow users of your GitHub Enterprise Server instance to find and fix vulnerabilities in code dependencies by  setting up  Dependabot alerts and Dependabot updates.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Enabling Server Statistics for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can analyze your own aggregate data from GitHub Enterprise Server and help us improve GitHub products by enabling Server Statistics.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Enabling unified search for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can allow users to include repositories on GitHub.com in their search results when searching from your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.title: Enabling unified contributions for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/configu.intro: You can allow users to include anonymized contribution counts for their work on your GitHub Enterprise Server instance in their contribution graphs on GitHub.com.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.title: Administering your instance
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.intro: You can administer your instance using the Management Console, site admin dashboard, SSH, and command-line utilities.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.title: Administering your instance from the web UI
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.intro: To perform administrative tasks for your GitHub Enterprise Server instance, you can use the Management Console and site admin dashboard.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.title: About the Management Console
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.intro: From the Management Console, you can initialize, configure, and monitor your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.title: Managing access to the Management Console
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.intro: You can increase the security of your GitHub Enterprise Server instance by creating or deleting Management Console users. As the root site administrator, you can access the Management Console as well as configure Management Console authentication rate limits.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.title: Accessing the Management Console
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.intro: You can access the Management Console as the root site administrator or a Management Console user.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.title: Troubleshooting access to the Management Console
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.intro: You can troubleshoot access problems for the Management Console.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.title: Site admin dashboard
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.intro: You can use the site admin dashboard to manage users, organizations, and repositories on your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.title: Administering your instance from the command line
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.intro: You can use the administrative shell (SSH) and command-line utilities to perform administrative tasks for your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.title: Accessing the administrative shell (SSH)
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.intro: SSH access allows you to run the GitHub Enterprise Server command line utilities to troubleshoot, run backups, and configure replication.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.title: Administering your instance using the GitHub CLI
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.intro: You can administer your GitHub Enterprise Server instance using the GitHub CLI extension for GHES Manage API.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.title: Command-line utilities
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.intro: GitHub Enterprise Server includes a variety of utilities to help resolve particular problems or perform specific tasks.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.title: Configuring maintenance mode
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.intro: To control availability of your GitHub Enterprise Server instance during maintenance, you can configure maintenance mode.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.title: Enabling and scheduling maintenance mode
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/adminis.intro: Some standard maintenance procedures, such as upgrading your GitHub Enterprise Server instance or restoring backups, require the instance to be taken offline for normal use.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Identity and access management
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can configure how people access your enterprise on GitHub Enterprise Cloud.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Understanding IAM for enterprises
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can invite existing personal accounts on GitHub.com to be members of your enterprise, and you can optionally enable SAML single sign-on (SSO) to centrally manage access. Alternatively, you can use Enterprise Managed Users with SAML SSO to create and control the accounts of your enterprise members.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: About identity and access management
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: Administrators for GitHub Enterprise Cloud must decide how users will access the enterprise's resources on GitHub.com.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: About SAML for enterprise IAM
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can use SAML single sign-on (SSO) to centrally manage access to organizations owned by your enterprise on GitHub.com.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: About Enterprise Managed Users
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can centrally manage identity and access for your enterprise members on GitHub from your identity provider (IdP).

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Abilities and restrictions of managed user accounts
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: If you centrally manage identity and access for your enterprise members on GitHub from your identity provider (IdP), some abilities and restrictions apply for your users' experience on GitHub.com.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Identifying the best authentication method for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can determine whether your enterprise would benefit more from SAML SSO or Enterprise Managed Users by asking yourself some questions about your enterprise's needs and workflows.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.title: Changing authentication methods
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.intro: You can change the way GitHub Enterprise Server authenticates with your existing accounts at any time.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.title: Allowing built-in authentication for users outside your provider
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.intro: You can configure fallback authentication to allow built-in authentication for people who don't have an account on your CAS, LDAP, or SAML authentication provider.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Troubleshooting identity and access management for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: Review common issues and solutions for identity and access management for your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: IAM configuration reference
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can view reference information about configuration of authentication and provisioning for your enterprise on GitHub Enterprise Cloud.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: SAML configuration reference
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can see SAML metadata for your organization or enterprise on GitHub Enterprise Cloud, and you can learn more about available SAML attributes and response requirements.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Username considerations for external authentication
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: When you use Enterprise Managed Users, GitHub Enterprise Cloud follows certain rules to determine the username for each user account in your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.title: Using built-in authentication
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.intro: If you don't use a centralized, external system for your users' identity, you can use built-in authentication to allow GitHub Enterprise Server to manage accounts and perform local authentication.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.title: Configuring built-in authentication
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.intro: When you use the default authentication method, all authentication details are stored on your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.title: Inviting people to use your instance
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.intro: When you use built-in authentication for GitHub Enterprise Server, you can invite people by email address to create a user account on your instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.title: Disabling unauthenticated sign-ups
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.intro: If you're using built-in authentication for your GitHub Enterprise Server instance, you can block unauthenticated people from creating new user accounts on your instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.title: Using CAS for enterprise IAM
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.intro: You can centrally manage accounts and access to your GitHub Enterprise Server instance by integrating with your existing CAS identity provider (IdP).

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.title: Using CAS
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.intro: If you use Central Authentication Service (CAS) to centralize access to multiple web applications, you can integrate GitHub Enterprise Server by configuring CAS authentication for your instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.title: Using LDAP for enterprise IAM
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.intro: You can centrally manage accounts and access to your GitHub Enterprise Server instance by integrating with your existing LDAP directory.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.title: Using LDAP
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.intro: If you use Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) to centralize access across applications, you can integrate GitHub Enterprise Server by configuring LDAP authentication for your instance.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Using SAML for enterprise IAM
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can centrally manage access to your enterprise's resources with SAML single sign-on (SSO) and System for Cross-domain Identity Management (SCIM).

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Deciding whether to configure SAML for your enterprise or your organizations
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can configure SAML for your enterprise account, with the same configuration applying to all of its organizations, or you can create separate configurations for individual organizations.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Configuring SAML single sign-on for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can control and secure access to resources like repositories, issues, and pull requests within your enterprise's organizations by enforcing SAML single sign-on (SSO) through your identity provider (IdP).

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.title: Configuring user provisioning with SCIM for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.intro: You can configure System for Cross-domain Identity Management (SCIM) for your GitHub Enterprise Server instance, which automatically provisions user accounts when you assign the application for your instance to a user on your identity provider (IdP).

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Managing team synchronization for organizations in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can enable team synchronization between Azure AD and GitHub Enterprise Cloud to allow organizations owned by your enterprise account to manage team membership through IdP groups.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Configuring SAML single sign-on for your enterprise using Okta
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can use Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) single sign-on (SSO) with Okta to automatically manage access to your enterprise account on GitHub Enterprise Cloud.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Disabling SAML single sign-on for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can disable SAML single sign-on (SSO) for your enterprise account.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.title: Configuring authentication and provisioning for your enterprise using Azure AD
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.intro: You can use a tenant in Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) as an identity provider (IdP) to centrally manage authentication and user provisioning for your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.title: Enabling encrypted assertions
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.intro: You can improve your GitHub Enterprise Server instance's security with SAML single sign-on (SSO) by encrypting the messages that your SAML identity provider (IdP) sends.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.title: Updating a user's SAML NameID
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/identit.intro: When an account's NameID changes on your identity provider (IdP) and the person can no longer sign into your GitHub Enterprise Server instance, you must update the NameID mapping on your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Switching your SAML configuration from an organization to an enterprise account
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: Learn special considerations and best practices for replacing an organization-level SAML configuration with an enterprise-level SAML configuration.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Troubleshooting SAML authentication
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: If you use SAML single sign-on (SSO) and people are unable to authenticate to access GitHub.com, you can troubleshoot the problem.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Configuring authentication for Enterprise Managed Users
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can decide whether people use SAML or OIDC to authenticate, learn about support for conditional access policy, or disable authentication for your enterprise with managed users on GitHub.com.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Configuring SAML single sign-on for Enterprise Managed Users
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can automatically manage access to your enterprise account on GitHub by configuring Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) single sign-on (SSO).

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Configuring OIDC for Enterprise Managed Users
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can automatically manage access to your enterprise account on GitHub by configuring OpenID Connect (OIDC) single sign-on (SSO) and enable support for your IdP's Conditional Access Policy (CAP).

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: About support for your IdP's Conditional Access Policy
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: When your enterprise uses OIDC SSO, GitHub can validate access to your enterprise and its resources using your IdP's Conditional Access Policy (CAP).

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Disabling authentication for Enterprise Managed Users
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can disable SAML single sign-on (SSO) or OIDC for Enterprise Managed Users by using a recovery code to sign in as the setup user.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Provisioning user accounts for Enterprise Managed Users
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: Learn how to provision accounts and manage organization and team membership for users of your enterprise with managed users on GitHub.com.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Configuring SCIM provisioning for Enterprise Managed Users
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can manage the lifecycle of your enterprise's user accounts on GitHub.com from your identity provider (IdP) using System for Cross-domain Identity Management (SCIM).

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Configuring SCIM provisioning with Okta
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: If you use Okta as an identity provider (IdP), you can manage the lifecycle of your enterprise's user accounts on GitHub.com using System for Cross-domain Identity Management (SCIM).

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Provisioning users with SCIM using the REST API
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can manage the lifecycle of your enterprise's user accounts on GitHub.com from your identity provider (IdP) using GitHub's REST API for System for Cross-domain Identity Management (SCIM).

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Managing team memberships with identity provider groups
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can manage team and organization membership on GitHub Enterprise Cloud through your identity provider (IdP) by connecting IdP groups with teams within your enterprise with managed users.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Troubleshooting team membership with identity provider groups
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: If you manage team membership using groups on your identity provider (IdP), but team membership is not in sync, you can troubleshoot the problem.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Reconfiguring IAM for Enterprise Managed Users
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: If the systems you use for IAM change, you can migrate your users to the new configuration by reconfiguring your managed enterprise on GitHub.com.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Migrating your enterprise to a new identity provider or tenant
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can migrate your enterprise to a different identity provider (IdP) or Azure AD tenant.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Migrating from OIDC to SAML
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: If you're using OpenID Connect (OIDC) to authenticate members in your enterprise with managed users, you can migrate to SAML SSO.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Migrating from SAML to OIDC
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: If you're using SAML to authenticate members in your enterprise with managed users, you can migrate to OpenID Connect (OIDC) and benefit from support for your IdP's Conditional Access Policy.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Managing recovery codes for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: With SAML single sign-on recovery codes, you can access your enterprise account even when your identity provider is unavailable.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Downloading your enterprise account's single sign-on recovery codes
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: To ensure that you can access GitHub Enterprise Cloud if your identity provider (IdP) is unavailable, you should download your enterprise account's single sign-on (SSO) recovery codes.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.title: Accessing your enterprise account if your identity provider is unavailable
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identi.intro: You can sign into GitHub Enterprise Cloud even if your identity provider is unavailable by bypassing single sign-on (SSO) with a recovery code.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Managing accounts and repositories
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can manage accounts, organizations, and repositories in your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Communicating information to users in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can communicate information to users in your enterprise by customizing user messages and footers.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Customizing user messages for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can create custom messages that users will see on GitHub.com.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Configuring custom footers
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can give users easy access to enterprise-specific links by adding custom footers to GitHub Enterprise Cloud.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Managing users in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can audit user activity and manage user settings.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Roles in an enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: Everyone in an enterprise is a member of the enterprise. To control access to your enterprise's settings and data, you can assign different roles to members of your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Best practices for user security
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: Outside of instance-level security measures (SSL, subdomain isolation, configuring a firewall) that a site administrator can implement, there are steps your users can take to help protect your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Inviting people to manage your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can invite and remove enterprise owners and billing managers for your enterprise account.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Managing invitations to organizations within your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can retry or cancel invitations to organizations within your enterprise, either one by one or multiple at a time.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Managing organization members in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can add or remove members from an organization in bulk.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Promoting or demoting a site administrator
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: Site administrators can promote any normal user account to a site administrator, as well as demote other site administrators to regular users.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Managing support entitlements for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can grant enterprise members the ability to manage support tickets for your enterprise account.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Viewing people in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: To audit access to enterprise-owned resources or user license usage, enterprise owners can view every administrator and member of the enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Exporting membership information for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can export information about all of your enterprise's members from GitHub's web UI.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Viewing and managing a user's SAML access to your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can view and revoke an enterprise member's linked identity, active sessions, and authorized credentials.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Auditing users across your enterprise
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: The audit log dashboard shows site administrators the actions performed by all users and organizations across your enterprise within the current month and previous six months. The audit log includes details such as who performed the action, what the action was, and when the action was performed.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Impersonating a user
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: You can impersonate users and perform actions on their behalf, for troubleshooting, unblocking, and other legitimate reasons.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Removing a member from your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can remove an enterprise member from an enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Managing dormant users
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: A user account is considered to be dormant if it has not been active for 90 days.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Suspending and unsuspending users
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: If a user leaves or moves to a different part of the company, you should remove or modify their ability to access your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Placing a legal hold on a user or organization
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: You can place a legal hold on a user or organization to ensure that repositories they own cannot be permanently removed from your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Auditing SSH keys
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: Site administrators can initiate an instance-wide audit of SSH keys.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Rebuilding contributions data
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: You may need to rebuild contributions data to link existing commits to a user account.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Managing organizations in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can use organizations to group users within your company, such as divisions or groups working on similar projects, and manage access to repositories.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Best practices for structuring organizations in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: Learn to identify how many organizations to create within your enterprise, and how you should structure them.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Adding organizations to your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can add organizations to manage within your enterprise by creating a new organization, inviting an existing organization, or transferring an organization from a different enterprise account.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Configuring visibility for organization membership
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: You can set visibility for new organization members across your enterprise to public or private. You can also prevent members from changing their visibility from the default.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Preventing users from creating organizations
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: You can prevent users from creating organizations in your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Requiring two-factor authentication for an organization
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: You can require organization members and outside collaborators to enable two-factor authentication for their personal accounts in an organization, making it harder for malicious actors to access an organization's repositories and settings.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Managing your role in an organization owned by your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can manage your membership in any organization owned by your enterprise and change your role within the organization.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Removing organizations from your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: If an organization should no longer be a part of your enterprise, you can remove the organization.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Restoring a deleted organization
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: You can partially restore an organization that was previously deleted on your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Managing projects using Jira
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: You can integrate Jira with GitHub Enterprise Server for project management.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Continuous integration using Jenkins
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: You can automatically trigger build jobs on a Jenkins server when pushes are made to a repository in your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Managing repositories in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can manage repositories in your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Viewing user-owned repositories in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can view all repositories owned by users within your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.title: Accessing user-owned repositories in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/managi.intro: You can temporarily access a repository owned by a user within your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Configuring Git Large File Storage for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: Git Large File Storage (Git LFS) is an open source extension to Git that allows you to work with large files the same way as other text files.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Migrating to internal repositories
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: You can migrate to internal repositories to unify the innersource experience for developers using both GitHub Enterprise Server and GitHub Enterprise Cloud.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Disabling Git SSH access on your enterprise
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: You can prevent people from using Git over SSH for certain or all repositories on your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Locking a repository
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: You can prevent changes to a repository's code and other resources, such as issues and pull requests, by locking the repository.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Restoring a deleted repository
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: You can restore deleted repositories to recover their contents.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.title: Troubleshooting service hooks
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/managin.intro: If payloads aren't being delivered, check for these common problems.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/backing.title: Backing up and restoring your instance
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/backing.intro: You can configure backups for your instance and troubleshoot common backup problems.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/backing.title: Configuring backups on your instance
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/backing.intro: As part of a disaster recovery plan, you can protect production data on your GitHub Enterprise Server instance by configuring automated backups.

/en/enterprise-server@3.9/admin/backing-.title: Known issues with backups for your instance
/en/enterprise-server@3.9/admin/backing-.intro: See an overview of workarounds for issues that impact the backup or restoration process for GitHub Enterprise Server.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.title: Setting policies for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.intro: You can set policies in GitHub Enterprise Cloud to reduce risk and increase quality.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.title: Enforcing policies for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.intro: You can configure policies for organizations in your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.title: About enterprise policies
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.intro: With enterprise policies, you can manage the policies for all the organizations owned by your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.title: Enforcing repository management policies in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.intro: You can enforce policies for repository management within your enterprise's organizations, or allow policies to be set in each organization.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.title: Enforcing team policies in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.intro: You can enforce policies for teams in your enterprise's organizations, or allow policies to be set in each organization.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.title: Enforcing policies for projects in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.intro: You can enforce policies for projects and classic projects within your enterprise's organizations, or allow policies to be set in each organization.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.title: Restricting email notifications for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.intro: You can prevent your enterprise's information from leaking into personal email accounts by restricting the domains where members can receive email notifications about activity in organizations owned by your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.title: Enforcing policies for GitHub Sponsors in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.intro: Enterprise owners can control whether to allow the enterprise's organizations to sponsor open source projects.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.title: Enforcing policies for security settings in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.intro: You can enforce policies to manage security settings in your enterprise's organizations, or allow policies to be set in each organization.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.title: Enforcing policies for GitHub Actions in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.intro: You can enforce policies for GitHub Actions within your enterprise's organizations, or allow policies to be set in each organization.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.title: Enforcing policies for GitHub Copilot in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.intro: You can enforce policies for GitHub Copilot Business within your enterprise's organizations, or allow policies to be set in each organization.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.title: Enforcing policies for GitHub Codespaces in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.intro: You can enforce policies for GitHub Codespaces within your enterprise's organizations.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.title: Enforcing policies for code security and analysis for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.intro: You can enforce policies to manage the use of code security and analysis features within your enterprise's organizations.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.title: Enforcing policies for personal access tokens in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/polici.intro: Enterprise owners can control whether to allow fine-grained personal access tokens and personal access tokens (classic), and can require approval for fine-grained personal access tokens.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/policie.title: Enforcing policy with pre-receive hooks
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/policie.intro: Use pre-receive hooks to enforce workflow standards within your organization. Pre-receive hooks require code to pass a pre-defined set of quality checks before the push is accepted into the repository.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/policie.title: About pre-receive hooks
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/policie.intro: Pre-receive hooks are scripts that run on the GitHub Enterprise Server appliance that you can use to implement quality checks.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/policie.title: Creating a pre-receive hook environment
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/policie.intro: To execute pre-receive hooks, use either the default pre-receive environment, or create a custom environment.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/policie.title: Creating a pre-receive hook script
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/policie.intro: Use pre-receive hook scripts to create requirements for accepting or rejecting a push based on the contents.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/policie.title: Managing pre-receive hooks on your instance
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/policie.intro: Configure how people will use pre-receive hooks on your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.title: Monitoring activity in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.intro: You can view user and system activity by leveraging audit logsand webhooks.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.title: Reviewing audit logs for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.intro: You can view user and system activity in the audit logs for your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.title: About the audit log for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.intro: To support debugging and internal and external compliance, GitHub Enterprise Cloud provides logs of audited user, organization, and repository events.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.title: Accessing the audit log for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.intro: You can view aggregated actions from all of the organizations owned by an enterprise account in the enterprise's audit log.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Configuring the audit log for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: You can configure settings for your enterprise's audit log.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.title: Displaying IP addresses in the audit log for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.intro: You can display the source IP address for events in your enterprise's audit log.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.title: Searching the audit log for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.intro: You can search an extensive list of audited actions in your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.title: Identifying audit log events performed by an access token
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.intro: You can identify the actions performed by a specific token in your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.title: Exporting audit log activity for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.intro: You can export audit and Git events data to a file for offline analysis.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.title: Streaming the audit log for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.intro: You can stream audit and Git events data from GitHub to an external data management system.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.title: Using the audit log API for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.intro: You can programmatically retrieve enterprise events with the REST API.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.title: Audit log events for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.intro: Learn about audit log events recorded for your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.title: Exploring user activity in your enterprise
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.intro: You can view user and system activity by leveraging dashboards, webhooks and log forwarding.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Activity dashboard
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: The Activity dashboard gives you an overview of all the activity in your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Viewing push logs
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: Site administrators can view a list of Git push operations for any repository on the enterprise.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Log forwarding
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: GitHub Enterprise Server uses syslog-ng to forward system and application logs to the server you specify.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.title: Managing global webhooks
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monito.intro: You can configure global webhooks to notify external web servers when events occur within your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Analyzing how your team works with Server Statistics
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: To analyze how your team works, understand the value you get from GitHub Enterprise Server, and help us improve our products, you can use Server Statistics to review your usage data for GitHub Enterprise Server and share this aggregate data with GitHub.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: About Server Statistics
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: You can use Server Statistics to analyze your own aggregate data from GitHub Enterprise Server, and help us improve GitHub products.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Exporting Server Statistics
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: You can use your own tools to analyze your GitHub Enterprise Server usage over time by downloading your Server Statistics metrics in a CSV or JSON file.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Requesting Server Statistics using the REST API
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: You can use your own tools to analyze your GitHub Enterprise Server usage over time by requesting the Server Statistics metrics collected using the REST API.

/en/enterprise-server@3.8/admin/monitori.title: Including data about GitHub Actions in Server Statistics
/en/enterprise-server@3.8/admin/monitori.intro: You can help us improve GitHub Actions by allowing Server Statistics to collect data about GitHub Actions.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Monitoring, managing, and updating your instance
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: You can monitor your instance, upgrade to a newer version, and configure clustering or high availability

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Monitoring your instance
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: As use of your GitHub Enterprise Server instance increases over time, the utilization of system resources, like CPU, memory, and storage will also increase. You can configure monitoring and alerting so that you're aware of potential issues before they become critical enough to negatively impact application performance or availability.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Accessing the monitor dashboard
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: GitHub Enterprise Server includes a web-based monitoring dashboard that displays historical data about your GitHub Enterprise Server appliance, such as CPU and storage usage, application and authentication response times, and general system health.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Recommended alert thresholds
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: You can configure an alert to notify you of system resource issues before they affect your GitHub Enterprise Server appliance's performance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Setting up external monitoring
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: You can monitor basic system resources on your GitHub Enterprise Server appliance using either the SNMP or collectd statistics collection protocols.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Configuring collectd for your instance
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: To gain insight into GitHub Enterprise Server's performance, you can review data from collectd on your instance, or optionally send the data to an external collectd server.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: collectd metrics for GitHub Enterprise Server
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: You can review the metrics that collectd gathers for your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Monitoring using SNMP
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: GitHub Enterprise provides data on disk usage, CPU utilization, memory usage, and more over SNMP.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: About system logs
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: To help administrators understand activity and errors, GitHub Enterprise Server stores system logs.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Generating a Health Check for your enterprise
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: You can gain insight into the general health and Git and API requests of your GitHub Enterprise Server instance by generating a Health Check.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Updating the virtual machine and physical resources
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: Upgrading the virtual software and virtual hardware requires some downtime for your instance, so be sure to plan your upgrade in advance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Upgrade requirements
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: Before upgrading GitHub Enterprise Server, review these recommendations and requirements to plan your upgrade strategy.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Upgrading GitHub Enterprise Server
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: Upgrade GitHub Enterprise Server to get the latest features and security updates.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Enabling automatic update checks
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: You can enable automatic update checks so that your GitHub Enterprise Server instance checks for and downloads the latest GitHub Enterprise Server release.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Increasing storage capacity
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: You can increase or change the amount of storage available for Git repositories, databases, search indexes, and other persistent application data.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Increasing CPU or memory resources
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: You can increase the CPU or memory resources for the virtual machine (VM) that runs your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Migrating from GitHub Enterprise 11.10.x to 2.1.23
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: To migrate from GitHub Enterprise 11.10.x to 2.1.23, you'll need to set up a new appliance instance and migrate data from the previous instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Known issues with upgrades to your instance
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: See an overview of workarounds for issues that impact the upgrade process for GitHub Enterprise Server, or impact your instance after you complete an upgrade.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Configuring clustering
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: The cluster topology for GitHub Enterprise Server provides horizontal scaling for environments with tens of thousands of developers.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: About clustering
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: The cluster topology for GitHub Enterprise Server is designed to support tens of thousands of users where other topologies would experience resource exhaustion. In a cluster, the instance's services scale horizontally across multiple nodes.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Differences between clustering and high availability (HA)
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: Learn about the differences between deployment topologies for the virtual machines (VMs) that comprise a GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: About cluster nodes
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: In a GitHub Enterprise Server cluster, nodes are individual virtual machines (VMs) running the GitHub Enterprise Server software that comprise the instance. Each node runs a set of services.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Cluster network configuration
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: A GitHub Enterprise Server cluster requires proper DNS name resolution, load balancing, and communication between nodes.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Initializing the cluster
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: A GitHub Enterprise Server cluster must be set up with a license and initialized using the administrative shell (SSH).

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Upgrading a cluster
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: To upgrade a GitHub Enterprise Server cluster to the latest release, use the administrative shell (SSH).

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Monitoring the health of your cluster
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: To ensure the performance and redundancy of a GitHub Enterprise Server cluster, you can monitor the cluster's health.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Monitoring the health of your cluster nodes with Node Eligibility Service
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: You can monitor when nodes in a GitHub Enterprise Server cluster have been offline long enough to cause issues by using Node Eligibility Service.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Rebalancing cluster workloads
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: You can force your GitHub Enterprise Server cluster to evenly distribute job allocations for workloads on the cluster's nodes.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Evacuating a cluster node running data services
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: If a node in your GitHub Enterprise Server cluster runs services that store distributed data, you can ensure redundancy as you prepare to replace the node by evacuating the node's data.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Replacing a cluster node
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.intro: If a node fails in a GitHub Enterprise Server cluster, or if you want to add a new node with more resources, mark any nodes to replace as offline, then add the new node.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/admin/monitor.title: Configuring high availability replication for a cluster
