/en/migrations.title: Migrations documentation
/en/migrations.intro: If you're moving to GitHub from another code hosting platform or moving between GitHub products, learn how to use our migration tooling to bring your work with you.

/en/migrations/overview.title: Overview
/en/migrations/overview.intro: Learn about GitHub's migration tooling options and how to plan your migration.

/en/migrations/overview/about-githubs-mi.title: About GitHub's migration tooling
/en/migrations/overview/about-githubs-mi.intro: GitHub provides a variety of different tooling options to support migrations to GitHub and between GitHub products.

/en/migrations/overview/planning-your-mi.title: Planning your migration to GitHub
/en/migrations/overview/planning-your-mi.intro: Learn how to plan and execute a successful migration to GitHub or between GitHub products.

/en/migrations/overview/migration-paths-.title: Migration paths to GitHub
/en/migrations/overview/migration-paths-.intro: See an overview of the paths available for migration to GitHub from other products, or between GitHub products.

/en/migrations/overview/about-locked-rep.title: About locked repositories
/en/migrations/overview/about-locked-rep.intro: Repositories can be locked to prevent changes, often for migrations.

/en/migrations/overview/programmatically.title: Programmatically importing repositories
/en/migrations/overview/programmatically.intro: You can programmatically import repositories to GitHub.com.

/en/migrations/importing-source-code.title: Importing source code
/en/migrations/importing-source-code.intro: To import source code only, you can use GitHub Importer or command line tools.

/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.title: Using GitHub Importer
/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.intro: To import repositories that are publicly accessible, you can use GitHub Importer.

/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.title: About GitHub Importer
/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.intro: If your source code is stored on a code hosting service using Git, Subversion, Mercurial, or Team Foundation Version Control (TFVC) and is accessible from the public internet, you can move the code to GitHub using GitHub Importer.

/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.title: Importing a repository with GitHub Importer
/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.intro: If you have a project hosted on another version control system, you can automatically import it to GitHub using the GitHub Importer tool.

/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.title: Updating commit author attribution with GitHub Importer
/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.intro: During an import, you can match commits in your repository with the GitHub account of the commit author.

/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.title: Using the command line to import source code
/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.intro: To import source code that is not accessible from the public internet, you can use command line tools.

/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.title: About source code imports using the command line
/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.intro: You can use command line tools to import source code and its revision history to GitHub.

/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.title: Adding locally hosted code to GitHub
/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.intro: If your code is stored locally on your computer and is tracked by Git or not tracked by any version control system (VCS), you can import the code to GitHub using GitHub CLI or Git commands.

/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.title: Importing an external Git repository using the command line
/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.intro: If your Git repository is stored on a code hosting service that is not accessible from the public internet, you can import the repository using Git on the command line.

/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.title: Importing a Subversion repository
/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.intro: You can import a repository from Subversion by converting the repository to Git, then pushing the Git repository to GitHub.

/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.title: Importing a Mercurial repository
/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.intro: You can import a repository from Mercurial by converting the repository to Git, then pushing the Git repository to GitHub.

/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.title: Importing a Team Foundation Version Control repository
/en/migrations/importing-source-code/usi.intro: You can import a repository from Team Foundation Version Control (TFVC) by converting the repository to Git, then pushing the Git repository to GitHub.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/migrations/im.title: Importing from other version control systems with the administrative shell
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/migrations/im.intro: Using the administrative shell, you can import from Subversion, Mercurial and Team Foundation Version Control to Git repositories on GitHub Enterprise Server.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Using GitHub Enterprise Importer
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: You can migrate your enterprise to GitHub Enterprise Cloud with GitHub Enterprise Importer.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Understanding GitHub Enterprise Importer
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: Learn about how GitHub Enterprise Importer can help you migrate to GitHub.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: About GitHub Enterprise Importer
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: With GitHub Enterprise Importer, you can migrate your enterprise to GitHub Enterprise Cloud from various sources.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Preparing to migrate with GitHub Enterprise Importer
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: You can prepare for your production migrations by making sure your user account has sufficient access and running trial migrations.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Preparing to run a migration with GitHub Enterprise Importer
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: Before running a production migration, we strongly recommend you perform a trial run of the migration with these best practices.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Migrating from Azure DevOps to GitHub Enterprise Cloud
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: You can migrate repositories to GitHub with GitHub Enterprise Importer.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: About migrations from Azure DevOps to GitHub Enterprise Cloud
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: Learn which data GitHub Enterprise Importer can migrate.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Overview of a migration from Azure DevOps to GitHub Enterprise Cloud
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: Learn how to complete the entire process of migrating from Azure DevOps to GitHub with GitHub Enterprise Importer, from planning to implementation to completing follow-up tasks.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Managing access for a migration from Azure DevOps
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: Before you use GitHub Enterprise Importer, make sure you have appropriate access to both the source and destination of your migration.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Migrating repositories from Azure DevOps to GitHub Enterprise Cloud
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: You can migrate repositories from Azure DevOps to GitHub Enterprise Cloud, using the GitHub CLI or the GraphQL API.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Migrating from Bitbucket Server to GitHub Enterprise Cloud
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: You can migrate repositories to GitHub with GitHub Enterprise Importer.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: About migrations from Bitbucket Server to GitHub Enterprise Cloud
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: Learn which data GitHub Enterprise Importer can migrate.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Overview of a migration from Bitbucket Server to GitHub Enterprise Cloud
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: Learn about the process of migrating from Bitbucket Server to GitHub with GitHub Enterprise Importer, from planning to implementation to completing follow-up tasks.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Managing access for a migration from Bitbucket Server
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: Before you use GitHub Enterprise Importer, make sure you have appropriate access to both the source and destination of your migration.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Migrating repositories from Bitbucket Server to GitHub Enterprise Cloud
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: You can migrate repositories from Bitbucket Server to GitHub Enterprise Cloud using the GitHub CLI.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Migrating between GitHub products
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: With GitHub Enterprise Importer, you can migrate from GitHub Enterprise Server to GitHub Enterprise Cloud, or migrate between accounts on GitHub Enterprise Cloud.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: About migrations between GitHub products
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: Learn which data GitHub Enterprise Importer can migrate between GitHub products.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Overview of a migration between GitHub products
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: Learn how to complete the entire process of migrating from one GitHub product to another with GitHub Enterprise Importer, from planning to implementation to completing follow-up tasks.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Managing access for a migration between GitHub products
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: Before you use GitHub Enterprise Importer, make sure you have appropriate access to both the source and destination of your migration.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Migrating repositories from GitHub Enterprise Server to GitHub Enterprise Cloud
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: You can migrate repositories from GitHub Enterprise Server to GitHub Enterprise Cloud, using the GitHub CLI or API.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Migrating repositories from GitHub.com to GitHub Enterprise Cloud
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: You can migrate repositories from GitHub.com to GitHub Enterprise Cloud, using the GitHub CLI or the GraphQL API.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Migrating organizations from GitHub.com to GitHub Enterprise Cloud
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: You can migrate organizations from GitHub.com to GitHub Enterprise Cloud, using the GitHub CLI or the GraphQL API.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Completing your migration with GitHub Enterprise Importer
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: After you migrate repositories to GitHub, you can access migration logs, reclaim mannequins, and troubleshoot any unexpected results.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Accessing your migration logs for GitHub Enterprise Importer
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: After running a migration, you should review the migration log to check for data that didn't migrate as expected.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Reclaiming mannequins for GitHub Enterprise Importer
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: After your migration, you can assign the history of a placeholder identity, or mannequin, to a member of your organization.

/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.title: Troubleshooting your migration with GitHub Enterprise Importer
/en/migrations/using-github-enterprise-i.intro: If your migration fails or produces unexpected results, you can try common troubleshooting steps.

/en/migrations/using-ghe-migrator.title: Using ghe-migrator
/en/migrations/using-ghe-migrator.intro: You can use ghe-migrator to migrate user, organization, and repository data to your GitHub Enterprise Server instance from GitHub.com or another GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/migrations/using-ghe-migrator/about-.title: About ghe-migrator
/en/migrations/using-ghe-migrator/about-.intro: You can use ghe-migrator to transfer data from a source location (either a GitHub.com organization or a GitHub Enterprise Server instance) to a target GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/migrations/using-ghe-migrator/export.title: Exporting migration data from GitHub Enterprise Server
/en/migrations/using-ghe-migrator/export.intro: To change platforms or move from a trial instance to a production instance, you can export migration data from a GitHub Enterprise Server instance by preparing the instance, locking the repositories, and generating a migration archive.

/en/migrations/using-ghe-migrator/export.title: Exporting migration data from GitHub.com
/en/migrations/using-ghe-migrator/export.intro: You can export migration data from an organization on GitHub.com by using the API to select repositories to migrate, then generating a migration archive that you can import into a GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/migrations/using-ghe-migrator/migrat.title: Migrating data to GitHub Enterprise Server
/en/migrations/using-ghe-migrator/migrat.intro: After generating a migration archive, you can import the data to your target GitHub Enterprise Server instance. You'll be able to review changes for potential conflicts before permanently applying the changes to your target instance.

/en/packages.title: GitHub Packages documentation
/en/packages.intro: Learn to safely publish and consume packages, store your packages alongside your code, and share your packages privately with your team or publicly with the open source community. You can also automate your packages with GitHub Actions.

/en/packages/quickstart.title: Quickstart for GitHub Packages
/en/packages/quickstart.intro: Publish to GitHub Packages with GitHub Actions.

/en/packages/learn-github-packages.title: Learn GitHub Packages
/en/packages/learn-github-packages.intro: You can find out more about using packages in GitHub, including publishing new packages to GitHub Packages, view and install existing packages, and, in special circumstances, delete existing packages.

/en/packages/learn-github-packages/intro.title: Introduction to GitHub Packages
/en/packages/learn-github-packages/intro.intro: GitHub Packages is a software package hosting service that allows you to host your software packages privately or publicly and use packages as dependencies in your projects.

/en/packages/learn-github-packages/about.title: About permissions for GitHub Packages
/en/packages/learn-github-packages/about.intro: Learn about how to manage permissions for your packages.

/en/packages/learn-github-packages/confi.title: Configuring a package's access control and visibility
/en/packages/learn-github-packages/confi.intro: Choose who has read, write, or admin access to your package and the visibility of your packages on GitHub.

/en/packages/learn-github-packages/conne.title: Connecting a repository to a package
/en/packages/learn-github-packages/conne.intro: You can connect a repository to a package on GitHub.com.

/en/packages/learn-github-packages/publi.title: Publishing a package
/en/packages/learn-github-packages/publi.intro: You can publish a package to GitHub Packages to make the package available for others to download and re-use.

/en/packages/learn-github-packages/viewi.title: Viewing packages
/en/packages/learn-github-packages/viewi.intro: You can see details about packages published to a repository, and narrow results by organization or user.

/en/packages/learn-github-packages/insta.title: Installing a package
/en/packages/learn-github-packages/insta.intro: You can install a package from GitHub Packages and use the package as a dependency in your own project.

/en/packages/learn-github-packages/delet.title: Deleting and restoring a package
/en/packages/learn-github-packages/delet.intro: Learn how to delete or restore a package.

/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.title: Working with a GitHub Packages registry
/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.intro: Learn how to use a supported GitHub Packages registry.

/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.title: Working with the Container registry
/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.intro: You can store and manage Docker and OCI images in the Container registry, which uses the package namespace https://ghcr.io.

/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.title: Working with the Docker registry
/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.intro: The Docker registry has now been replaced by the Container registry.

/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.title: Working with the RubyGems registry
/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.intro: You can configure RubyGems to publish a package to GitHub Packages and to use packages stored on GitHub Packages as dependencies in a Ruby project with Bundler.

/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.title: Working with the npm registry
/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.intro: You can configure npm to publish packages to GitHub Packages and to use packages stored on GitHub Packages as dependencies in an npm project.

/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.title: Working with the Apache Maven registry
/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.intro: You can configure Apache Maven to publish packages to GitHub Packages and to use packages stored on GitHub Packages as dependencies in a Java project.

/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.title: Working with the Gradle registry
/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.intro: You can configure Gradle to publish packages to the GitHub Packages Gradle registry and to use packages stored on GitHub Packages as dependencies in a Java project.

/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.title: Working with the NuGet registry
/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.intro: You can configure the dotnet command-line interface (CLI) to publish NuGet packages to GitHub Packages and to use packages stored on GitHub Packages as dependencies in a .NET project.

/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.title: Migrating to the Container registry from the Docker registry
/en/packages/working-with-a-github-packa.intro: GitHub will migrate Docker images previously stored in the Docker registry on GitHub.com to the Container registry.

/en/packages/managing-github-packages-us.title: Managing GitHub packages using GitHub Actions workflows
/en/packages/managing-github-packages-us.intro: You can safely publish and consume packages by building custom workflows that can also build, test, and deploy your code.

/en/packages/managing-github-packages-us.title: Publishing and installing a package with GitHub Actions
/en/packages/managing-github-packages-us.intro: You can configure a workflow in GitHub Actions to automatically publish or install a package from GitHub Packages.

/en/packages/managing-github-packages-us.title: Example workflows for publishing a package
/en/packages/managing-github-packages-us.intro: To help you get started with your own custom workflows, review some example workflows for publishing packages.

/en/packages/managing-github-packages-us.title: About GitHub Packages and GitHub Actions
/en/packages/managing-github-packages-us.intro: Learn the fundamentals of managing packages through your GitHub Actions workflows.

/en/search-github.title: Search on GitHub documentation
/en/search-github.intro: Learn how to use the search functions available on GitHub to find different types of information, like projects, people, and code.

/en/search-github/getting-started-with-s.title: Getting started with searching on GitHub
/en/search-github/getting-started-with-s.intro: You can use a wide range of syntax to search GitHub. You can adjust the scope of your search, build and troubleshoot queries, and sort search results with qualifiers.

/en/search-github/getting-started-with-s.title: About searching on GitHub
/en/search-github/getting-started-with-s.intro: Our integrated search covers the many repositories, users, and lines of code on GitHub.

/en/search-github/getting-started-with-s.title: Understanding the search syntax
/en/search-github/getting-started-with-s.intro: When searching GitHub, you can construct queries that match specific numbers and words.

/en/search-github/getting-started-with-s.title: Troubleshooting search queries
/en/search-github/getting-started-with-s.intro: If you encounter unexpected results while searching on GitHub, you can troubleshoot by reviewing common problems and limitations.

/en/search-github/getting-started-with-s.title: Sorting search results
/en/search-github/getting-started-with-s.intro: You can sort GitHub search results using the Sort menu, or by adding a sort qualifier to your query.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/search-github.title: Enabling GitHub.com repository search from your private enterprise environment
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/search-github.intro: You can connect your personal accounts on GitHub.com and your private GitHub Enterprise environment to search for content in certain GitHub.com repositories from GitHub Enterprise Server.

/en/search-github/searching-on-github.title: Searching on GitHub
/en/search-github/searching-on-github.intro: You can use qualifiers to narrow your search and focus on specific categories of information.

/en/search-github/searching-on-github/fi.title: Finding files on GitHub
/en/search-github/searching-on-github/fi.intro: You can search for a file in a repository using the file finder. To search for a file in multiple repositories on GitHub, use the path code search qualifier.

/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.title: Searching for repositories
/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.intro: You can search for repositories on GitHub and narrow the results using these repository search qualifiers in any combination.

/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.title: Searching topics
/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.intro: You can search for topics associated with repositories on GitHub.

/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.title: Searching code (legacy)
/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.intro: You only need to use the legacy code search syntax if you are using the code search API.

/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.title: Searching commits
/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.intro: You can search for commits on GitHub and narrow the results using these commit search qualifiers in any combination.

/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.title: Searching issues and pull requests
/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.intro: You can search for issues and pull requests on GitHub and narrow the results using these search qualifiers in any combination.

/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.title: Searching discussions
/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.intro: You can search for discussions on GitHub and narrow the results using search qualifiers.

/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.title: Searching GitHub Marketplace
/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.intro: You can search for apps and actions that are available on GitHub Marketplace.

/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.title: Searching users
/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.intro: You can search for users on GitHub and narrow the results using these user search qualifiers in any combination.

/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.title: Searching for packages
/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.intro: You can search for packages on GitHub and narrow the results using search qualifiers.

/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.title: Searching wikis
/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.intro: You can search wikis on GitHub and narrow the results using these wiki search qualifiers in any combination.

/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.title: Searching in forks
/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.intro: By default, forks are not shown in search results. You can choose to include them in repository searches, and in code searches if they meet certain criteria.

/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.title: Searching gists
/en/search-github/searching-on-github/se.intro: You can search for gists on GitHub and narrow the results using search qualifiers.

/en/search-github/github-code-search.title: GitHub Code Search
/en/search-github/github-code-search.intro: Learn how to use code search to find, navigate, and understand code across GitHub.

/en/search-github/github-code-search/abo.title: About GitHub Code Search
/en/search-github/github-code-search/abo.intro: You can search, navigate and understand code across GitHub with code search.

/en/search-github/github-code-search/usi.title: Using GitHub Code Search
/en/search-github/github-code-search/usi.intro: You can use suggestions, completions and saved searches in the upgraded search interface to quickly find what you are looking for across GitHub.com.

/en/search-github/github-code-search/und.title: Understanding GitHub Code Search syntax
/en/search-github/github-code-search/und.intro: You can build search queries for the results you want with specialized code qualifiers, regular expressions, and boolean operations.

/en/apps.title: GitHub Apps documentation
/en/apps.intro: Go deeper with GitHub by integrating with our APIs and webhooks, customizing your GitHub workflow, and building and sharing apps with the community.

/en/apps/overview.title: GitHub Apps overview
/en/apps/overview.intro: You can use GitHub Apps to extend the functionality of GitHub.

/en/apps/using-github-apps.title: Using GitHub Apps
/en/apps/using-github-apps.intro: You can purchase and install GitHub Apps from GitHub Marketplace.

/en/apps/using-github-apps/about-using-g.title: About using GitHub Apps
/en/apps/using-github-apps/about-using-g.intro: Learn about what a GitHub App is and why you would use a GitHub App.

/en/apps/using-github-apps/installing-a-.title: Installing a GitHub App from GitHub Marketplace for your personal account
/en/apps/using-github-apps/installing-a-.intro: You can install GitHub Apps from GitHub Marketplace to use on your personal account.

/en/apps/using-github-apps/installing-a-.title: Installing a GitHub App from GitHub Marketplace for your organizations
/en/apps/using-github-apps/installing-a-.intro: You can install GitHub Apps from GitHub Marketplace to use on your organizations.

/en/apps/using-github-apps/installing-a-.title: Installing a GitHub App from a third party
/en/apps/using-github-apps/installing-a-.intro: You can install GitHub Apps directly from the app owner to use on your personal account or organizations.

/en/apps/using-github-apps/installing-yo.title: Installing your own GitHub App
/en/apps/using-github-apps/installing-yo.intro: You can install a GitHub App that you created on the personal or organization account that owns the app. If your app is public, the GitHub App can also be installed on other accounts.

/en/apps/using-github-apps/requesting-a-.title: Requesting a GitHub App from your organization owner
/en/apps/using-github-apps/requesting-a-.intro: Organization members can request installation of a GitHub App for their organization.

/en/apps/using-github-apps/authorizing-g.title: Authorizing GitHub Apps
/en/apps/using-github-apps/authorizing-g.intro: You can authorize a GitHub App to retrieve information about your GitHub account and to make changes on your behalf.

/en/apps/using-github-apps/approving-upd.title: Approving updated permissions for a GitHub App
/en/apps/using-github-apps/approving-upd.intro: When a GitHub App requests additional permissions, you can review what behavior the permissions will enable and decide whether to approve the permissions.

/en/apps/using-github-apps/reviewing-and.title: Reviewing and revoking authorization of GitHub Apps
/en/apps/using-github-apps/reviewing-and.intro: You can review the GitHub Apps that you have authorized, and you can revoke your authorization.

/en/apps/using-github-apps/reviewing-and.title: Reviewing and modifying installed GitHub Apps
/en/apps/using-github-apps/reviewing-and.intro: You can review the permissions and change the repository access for GitHub Apps that you have installed. You can also temporarily or permanently prevent a GitHub App from accessing resources owned by your account or organization.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/apps/using-g.title: SAML and GitHub Apps
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/apps/using-g.intro: If your organization uses SAML SSO, you may need to start an active SAML session for your organization before authorizing, installing, or requesting a GitHub App.

/en/apps/using-github-apps/internal-gith.title: Internal GitHub Apps
/en/apps/using-github-apps/internal-gith.intro: Some GitHub Apps are internal apps, owned by GitHub, that are granted special capabilities.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps.title: Creating GitHub Apps
/en/apps/creating-github-apps.intro: You can build GitHub Apps for yourself or others to use.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/about-crea.title: About creating GitHub Apps
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/about-crea.intro: Learn about how to create a GitHub App, including best practices and when to use a GitHub App.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/about-crea.title: About creating GitHub Apps
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/about-crea.intro: GitHub Apps let you build integrations to automate processes and extend GitHub's functionality.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/about-crea.title: Deciding when to build a GitHub App
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/about-crea.intro: When building an integration, you should consider using a GitHub App in the following scenarios, instead of an OAuth app, personal access token, or GitHub Actions.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/about-crea.title: Best practices for creating a GitHub App
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/about-crea.intro: Follow these best practices to improve the security and performance of your GitHub App.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/about-crea.title: Migrating OAuth apps to GitHub Apps
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/about-crea.intro: Learn about the advantages of migrating your OAuth app to a GitHub App, and learn how to migrate your OAuth app.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/registerin.title: Registering a GitHub App
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/registerin.intro: You can register a GitHub App under your personal account or under any organization you own.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/registerin.title: About the user authorization callback URL
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/registerin.intro: You can specify a URL that users will be redirected to after they authorize a GitHub App.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/registerin.title: About the setup URL
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/registerin.intro: You can specify a URL that users will be redirected to after they install a GitHub App.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/registerin.title: Choosing permissions for a GitHub App
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/registerin.intro: The permissions of a GitHub App determine what the app can do with GitHub's APIs and what webhooks the app can receive.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/registerin.title: Using webhooks with GitHub Apps
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/registerin.intro: Your GitHub App can subscribe to webhook events to receive notifications whenever certain activity occurs.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/registerin.title: Making a GitHub App public or private
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/registerin.intro: When registering a GitHub App, you can make it public so that other GitHub users or organizations can install the app, or private so that you can only install it on the account that owns the app.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/registerin.title: Rate limits for GitHub Apps
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/registerin.intro: Rate limits restrict the rate of traffic to GitHub.com, to help ensure consistent access for all users.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/registerin.title: Creating a custom badge for your GitHub App
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/registerin.intro: You can replace the default badge on your GitHub App by uploading your own logo image and customizing the background.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.title: Authenticating with a GitHub App
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.intro: Learn how to authenticate with GitHub Apps.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.title: About authentication with a GitHub App
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.intro: Your GitHub App can authenticate as itself, as an app installation, or on behalf of a user.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.title: Authenticating as a GitHub App
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.intro: You can authenticate as a GitHub App in order to generate an installation access token or manage your app.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.title: Authenticating as a GitHub App installation
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.intro: You can make your GitHub App authenticate as an installation in order to make API requests that affect resources owned by the account where the app is installed.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.title: Authenticating with a GitHub App on behalf of a user
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.intro: Your GitHub App can perform actions on behalf of a user, like creating an issue, posting a comment, or creating a deployment.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.title: Managing private keys for GitHub Apps
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.intro: You can manage private keys to authenticate with your GitHub App.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.title: Generating a JSON Web Token (JWT) for a GitHub App
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.intro: Learn how to create a JSON Web Token (JWT) to authenticate to certain REST API endpoints with your GitHub App.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.title: Generating an installation access token for a GitHub App
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.intro: Learn how to generate an installation access token for your GitHub App.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.title: Generating a user access token for a GitHub App
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.intro: You can generate a user access token for your GitHub App in order to attribute app activity to a user.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.title: Refreshing user access tokens
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.intro: To enforce regular token rotation and reduce the impact of a compromised token, you can configure your GitHub App to use user access tokens that expire.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.title: Making authenticated API requests with a GitHub App in a GitHub Actions workflow
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authentica.intro: You can use an installation access token from a GitHub App to make authenticated API requests in a GitHub Actions workflow. You can also pass the token to a custom action to enable the action to make authenticated API requests.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/writing-co.title: Writing code for a GitHub App
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/writing-co.intro: Learn about using the GitHub API with your app, continuous integration, and how to build with apps.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/writing-co.title: About writing code for a GitHub App
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/writing-co.intro: You need to write code to add functionality to your GitHub App.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/writing-co.title: Quickstart for building GitHub Apps
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/writing-co.intro: Quickly build a GitHub App that comments on pull requests.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/writing-co.title: Building a GitHub App that responds to webhook events
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/writing-co.intro: Learn how to build a GitHub App that makes an API request in response to a webhook event.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/writing-co.title: Building a "Login with GitHub" button with a GitHub App
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/writing-co.intro: Follow this tutorial to write Ruby code to generate a user access token via the web application flow for your GitHub App.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/writing-co.title: Building a CLI with a GitHub App
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/writing-co.intro: Follow this tutorial to write a CLI in Ruby that generates a user access token for a GitHub App via the device flow.

/en/apps/creating-github-apps/writing-co.title: Building CI checks with a GitHub App
/en/apps/creating-github-apps/writing-co.intro: Build a continuous integration server to run tests using a GitHub App and checks.

/en/apps/sharing-github-apps.title: Sharing GitHub Apps
/en/apps/sharing-github-apps.intro: After you create a public GitHub App, you can share your GitHub App with other GitHub users.

/en/apps/sharing-github-apps/sharing-you.title: Sharing your GitHub App
/en/apps/sharing-github-apps/sharing-you.intro: You can share your GitHub App with other users.

/en/apps/sharing-github-apps/making-your.title: Making your GitHub App available for GitHub Enterprise Server
/en/apps/sharing-github-apps/making-your.intro: In order for GitHub Enterprise Server instances to use your GitHub App, you must take some additional steps.

/en/apps/sharing-github-apps/registering.title: Registering a GitHub App from a manifest
/en/apps/sharing-github-apps/registering.intro: A GitHub App manifest is a way to share a preconfigured GitHub App registration with other users. The manifest flow allows someone to quickly register a GitHub App.

/en/apps/sharing-github-apps/registering.title: Registering a GitHub App using URL parameters
/en/apps/sharing-github-apps/registering.intro: You can use URL query parameters to help other people quickly set up a new GitHub App with a specific configuration you have preselected.

/en/apps/maintaining-github-apps.title: Maintaining GitHub Apps
/en/apps/maintaining-github-apps.intro: After you create and register a GitHub App, you can make modifications to the app, change permissions, transfer ownership, and delete the app.

/en/apps/maintaining-github-apps/modifyi.title: Modifying a GitHub App registration
/en/apps/maintaining-github-apps/modifyi.intro: After registering a GitHub App, you can make changes to it.

/en/apps/maintaining-github-apps/activat.title: Activating optional features for GitHub Apps
/en/apps/maintaining-github-apps/activat.intro: You can test new optional features for your GitHub Apps.

/en/apps/maintaining-github-apps/about-g.title: About GitHub App managers
/en/apps/maintaining-github-apps/about-g.intro: Organization owners can grant or revoke access for a user to manage some or all of the GitHub App registrations owned by the organization.

/en/apps/maintaining-github-apps/managin.title: Managing allowed IP addresses for a GitHub App
/en/apps/maintaining-github-apps/managin.intro: You can add an IP allow list to your GitHub App registration to prevent your app from being blocked by an organization's own allow list.

/en/apps/maintaining-github-apps/suspend.title: Suspending a GitHub App installation
/en/apps/maintaining-github-apps/suspend.intro: You can temporarily block your GitHub App from accessing resources owned by the accounts that installed the GitHub App.

/en/apps/maintaining-github-apps/transfe.title: Transferring ownership of a GitHub App
/en/apps/maintaining-github-apps/transfe.intro: You can transfer ownership of a GitHub App registration to another user or organization.

/en/apps/maintaining-github-apps/deletin.title: Deleting a GitHub App
/en/apps/maintaining-github-apps/deletin.intro: You can delete GitHub Apps that you own if you no longer want to use or maintain the app.

/en/apps/github-marketplace.title: GitHub Marketplace
/en/apps/github-marketplace.intro: List your tools in GitHub Marketplace for developers to use or purchase.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/github-marke.title: GitHub Marketplace Overview
/en/apps/github-marketplace/github-marke.intro: Learn how you can share your app or action with the GitHub community on GitHub Marketplace.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/github-marke.title: About GitHub Marketplace for apps
/en/apps/github-marketplace/github-marke.intro: Learn about GitHub Marketplace where you can share your apps publicly with all GitHub users.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/github-marke.title: About marketplace badges
/en/apps/github-marketplace/github-marke.intro: Learn about the badges that you may see for some apps listings on GitHub Marketplace.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/github-marke.title: Applying for publisher verification for your organization
/en/apps/github-marketplace/github-marke.intro: To offer paid plans for your app or to include a marketplace badge in your app listing, you must complete the publisher verification process for your organization.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/creating-app.title: Creating apps for GitHub Marketplace
/en/apps/github-marketplace/creating-app.intro: You can list free and paid tools for developers to use in GitHub Marketplace.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/creating-app.title: Requirements for listing an app
/en/apps/github-marketplace/creating-app.intro: Apps on GitHub Marketplace must meet the requirements outlined on this page before the listing can be published.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/creating-app.title: Security best practices for apps on GitHub Marketplace
/en/apps/github-marketplace/creating-app.intro: Guidelines for preparing a secure app to share on GitHub Marketplace.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/creating-app.title: Customer experience best practices for apps
/en/apps/github-marketplace/creating-app.intro: Guidelines for creating an app that will be easy to use and understand.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/creating-app.title: Viewing metrics for your listing
/en/apps/github-marketplace/creating-app.intro: The GitHub Marketplace Insights page displays metrics for your GitHub App. You can use the metrics to track your GitHub App's performance and make more informed decisions about pricing, plans, free trials, and how to visualize the effects of marketing campaigns.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/creating-app.title: Viewing transactions for your listing
/en/apps/github-marketplace/creating-app.intro: The GitHub Marketplace transactions page allows you to download and view all transactions for your GitHub Marketplace listing. You can view transactions for the past day (24 hours), week, month, or for the entire duration of time that your GitHub App has been listed.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/using-the-gi.title: Using the GitHub Marketplace API in your app
/en/apps/github-marketplace/using-the-gi.intro: Learn how to integrate the GitHub Marketplace API and webhook events into your app for the GitHub Marketplace .

/en/apps/github-marketplace/using-the-gi.title: REST endpoints for the GitHub Marketplace API
/en/apps/github-marketplace/using-the-gi.intro: To help manage your app on GitHub Marketplace, use these GitHub Marketplace API endpoints.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/using-the-gi.title: Webhook events for the GitHub Marketplace API
/en/apps/github-marketplace/using-the-gi.intro: A GitHub Marketplace app receives information about changes to a user's plan from the Marketplace purchase event webhook. A Marketplace purchase event is triggered when a user purchases, cancels, or changes their payment plan.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/using-the-gi.title: Testing your app
/en/apps/github-marketplace/using-the-gi.intro: GitHub recommends testing your app with APIs and webhooks before submitting your listing to GitHub Marketplace so you can provide an ideal experience for customers. Before an onboarding expert approves your app, it must adequately handle the billing flows.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/using-the-gi.title: Handling new purchases and free trials
/en/apps/github-marketplace/using-the-gi.intro: When a customer purchases a paid plan, free trial, or the free version of your GitHub Marketplace app, you'll receive the marketplace_purchase event webhook with the purchased action, which kicks off the purchasing flow.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/using-the-gi.title: Handling plan changes
/en/apps/github-marketplace/using-the-gi.intro: Upgrading or downgrading a GitHub Marketplace app triggers the marketplace_purchase event webhook with the changed action, which kicks off the upgrade or downgrade flow.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/using-the-gi.title: Handling plan cancellations
/en/apps/github-marketplace/using-the-gi.intro: Cancelling a GitHub Marketplace app triggers the marketplace_purchase event webhook with the cancelled action, which kicks off the cancellation flow.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/listing-an-a.title: Listing an app on GitHub Marketplace
/en/apps/github-marketplace/listing-an-a.intro: Learn about requirements and best practices for listing your app on GitHub Marketplace.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/listing-an-a.title: Drafting a listing for your app
/en/apps/github-marketplace/listing-an-a.intro: When you create a GitHub Marketplace listing, GitHub saves it in draft mode until you submit the app for approval. Your listing shows customers how they can use your app.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/listing-an-a.title: Writing a listing description for your app
/en/apps/github-marketplace/listing-an-a.intro: To list your app in the GitHub Marketplace, you'll need to write descriptions of your app and provide images that follow GitHub's guidelines.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/listing-an-a.title: Setting pricing plans for your listing
/en/apps/github-marketplace/listing-an-a.intro: When you list your app on GitHub Marketplace, you can choose to provide your app as a free service or sell your app. If you plan to sell your app, you can create different pricing plans for different feature tiers.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/listing-an-a.title: Configuring a webhook to notify you of plan changes
/en/apps/github-marketplace/listing-an-a.intro: After creating a draft GitHub Marketplace listing, you can configure a webhook that notifies you when changes to customer account plans occur. After you configure the webhook, you can handle the marketplace_purchase event types in your app.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/listing-an-a.title: Submitting your listing for publication
/en/apps/github-marketplace/listing-an-a.intro: To finish your app listing submission, you can request a review by an onboarding expert.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/listing-an-a.title: Deleting your GitHub App listing from GitHub Marketplace
/en/apps/github-marketplace/listing-an-a.intro: To delete your GitHub App listing from GitHub Marketplace, you must contact GitHub Support.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/selling-your.title: Selling your app on GitHub Marketplace
/en/apps/github-marketplace/selling-your.intro: Learn about requirements and best practices for selling your app on GitHub Marketplace.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/selling-your.title: Pricing plans for GitHub Marketplace apps
/en/apps/github-marketplace/selling-your.intro: Pricing plans allow you to provide your app with different levels of service or resources. You can offer up to 10 pricing plans in your GitHub Marketplace listing.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/selling-your.title: Billing customers
/en/apps/github-marketplace/selling-your.intro: Apps on GitHub Marketplace should adhere to GitHub's billing guidelines and support recommended services. Following our guidelines helps customers navigate the billing process without any surprises.

/en/apps/github-marketplace/selling-your.title: Receiving payment for app purchases
/en/apps/github-marketplace/selling-your.intro: At the end of each month, you'll receive payment for your GitHub Marketplace listing.

/en/apps/oauth-apps.title: OAuth apps
/en/apps/oauth-apps.intro: Learn how to build and maintain OAuth apps.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/using-oauth-apps.title: Using OAuth apps
/en/apps/oauth-apps/using-oauth-apps.intro: You can authorize third-party OAuth apps, and review the OAuth apps you authorized.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/using-oauth-apps/ins.title: Installing an OAuth app in your personal account
/en/apps/oauth-apps/using-oauth-apps/ins.intro: You can install OAuth apps from GitHub Marketplace to use in your personal account.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/using-oauth-apps/ins.title: Installing an OAuth app in your organization
/en/apps/oauth-apps/using-oauth-apps/ins.intro: You can install OAuth apps from GitHub Marketplace to use in your organization.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/using-oauth-apps/aut.title: Authorizing OAuth apps
/en/apps/oauth-apps/using-oauth-apps/aut.intro: You can connect your GitHub identity to third-party applications using OAuth. When authorizing an OAuth app, you should ensure you trust the application, review who it's developed by, and review the kinds of information the application wants to access.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/using-oauth-apps/rev.title: Reviewing your authorized OAuth apps
/en/apps/oauth-apps/using-oauth-apps/rev.intro: You should review your authorized applications to verify that no new applications with expansive permissions are authorized, such as those that have access to your private repositories.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/using-oauth-apps/con.title: Connecting with third-party applications
/en/apps/oauth-apps/using-oauth-apps/con.intro: You can connect your GitHub identity to third-party applications using OAuth. When authorizing one of these applications, you should ensure you trust the application, review who it's developed by, and review the kinds of information the application wants to access.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/using-oauth-apps/int.title: Internal OAuth apps
/en/apps/oauth-apps/using-oauth-apps/int.intro: Some OAuth apps are internal apps, owned by GitHub, that are granted special capabilities.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps.title: Building OAuth apps
/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps.intro: You can build OAuth apps for yourself or others to use. Learn how to register and set up permissions and authorization options for OAuth apps.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps/.title: Differences between GitHub Apps and OAuth apps
/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps/.intro: In general, GitHub Apps are preferred to OAuth apps because they use fine-grained permissions, give more control over which repositories the app can access, and use short-lived tokens.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps/.title: Rate limits for OAuth apps
/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps/.intro: Rate limits restrict the rate of traffic to GitHub.com, to help ensure consistent access for all users.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps/.title: Creating an OAuth app
/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps/.intro: You can create and register an OAuth app under your personal account or under any organization you have administrative access to. While creating your OAuth app, remember to protect your privacy by only using information you consider public.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps/.title: Authenticating to the REST API with an OAuth app
/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps/.intro: Learn about the different ways to authenticate with some examples.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps/.title: Authorizing OAuth apps
/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps/.intro: You can enable other users to authorize your OAuth app.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps/.title: Scopes for OAuth apps
/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps/.intro: Scopes let you specify exactly what type of access you need. Scopes limit access for OAuth tokens. They do not grant any additional permission beyond that which the user already has.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps/.title: Creating a custom badge for your OAuth app
/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps/.intro: You can replace the default badge on your OAuth app by uploading your own logo image and customizing the background.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps/.title: Best practices for creating an OAuth app
/en/apps/oauth-apps/building-oauth-apps/.intro: Follow these best practices to improve the security and performance of your OAuth app.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/maintaining-oauth-ap.title: Maintaining OAuth apps
/en/apps/oauth-apps/maintaining-oauth-ap.intro: After you create and register an OAuth app, you can make modifications to the app, change permissions, transfer ownership, and delete the app.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/maintaining-oauth-ap.title: Modifying an OAuth app
/en/apps/oauth-apps/maintaining-oauth-ap.intro: After creating and registering an OAuth app, you can make changes to it.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/maintaining-oauth-ap.title: Activating optional features for OAuth apps
/en/apps/oauth-apps/maintaining-oauth-ap.intro: You can test new optional features for your OAuth apps.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/maintaining-oauth-ap.title: Transferring ownership of an OAuth app
/en/apps/oauth-apps/maintaining-oauth-ap.intro: You can transfer ownership of an OAuth app to another user or organization.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/maintaining-oauth-ap.title: Troubleshooting authorization request errors
/en/apps/oauth-apps/maintaining-oauth-ap.intro: When obtaining an OAuth token for a user, some errors may occur during the initial authorization request phase.

/en/apps/oauth-apps/maintaining-oauth-ap.title: Troubleshooting OAuth app access token request errors
/en/apps/oauth-apps/maintaining-oauth-ap.intro: When exchanging a code for an access token, there are an additional set of errors that can occur. The format of these responses is determined by the accept header you pass.

/en/graphql.title: GitHub GraphQL API documentation
/en/graphql.intro: To create integrations, retrieve data, and automate your workflows, use the GitHub GraphQL API. The GitHub GraphQL API offers more precise and flexible queries than the GitHub REST API.

/en/graphql/overview.title: Overview
/en/graphql/overview.intro: Learn about the GitHub GraphQL API, previews for upcoming changes, breaking changes, and limitations. You can also use the GraphQL Explorer to interact with the API on real GitHub data.

/en/graphql/overview/about-the-graphql-a.title: About the GraphQL API
/en/graphql/overview/about-the-graphql-a.intro: The GitHub GraphQL API offers flexibility and the ability to define precisely the data you want to fetch.

/en/graphql/overview/public-schema.title: Public schema
/en/graphql/overview/public-schema.intro: Download the public schema for the GitHub GraphQL API.

/en/graphql/overview/schema-previews.title: Schema previews
/en/graphql/overview/schema-previews.intro: You can preview upcoming features and changes to the GitHub GraphQL schema before they are added to the GitHub GraphQL API.

/en/graphql/overview/breaking-changes.title: Breaking changes
/en/graphql/overview/breaking-changes.intro: Learn about recent and upcoming breaking changes to the GitHub GraphQL API.

/en/graphql/overview/changelog.title: Changelog
/en/graphql/overview/changelog.intro: The GraphQL schema changelog is a list of recent and upcoming changes to our GraphQL API schema. It includes backwards-compatible changes, schema previews, and upcoming breaking changes.

/en/graphql/overview/rate-limits-and-nod.title: Rate limits and node limits for the GraphQL API
/en/graphql/overview/rate-limits-and-nod.intro: The GitHub GraphQL API has limitations in place to protect against excessive or abusive calls to GitHub's servers.

/en/graphql/reference.title: Reference
/en/graphql/reference.intro: View reference documentation to learn about the data types available in the GitHub GraphQL API schema.

/en/graphql/reference/queries.title: Queries
/en/graphql/reference/queries.intro: The query type defines GraphQL operations that retrieve data from the server.

/en/graphql/reference/mutations.title: Mutations
/en/graphql/reference/mutations.intro: The mutation type defines GraphQL operations that change data on the server.

/en/graphql/reference/objects.title: Objects
/en/graphql/reference/objects.intro: Objects in GraphQL represent the resources you can access.

/en/graphql/reference/interfaces.title: Interfaces
/en/graphql/reference/interfaces.intro: Interfaces serve as parent objects from which other objects can inherit.

/en/graphql/reference/enums.title: Enums
/en/graphql/reference/enums.intro: Enums represent possible sets of values for a field.

/en/graphql/reference/unions.title: Unions
/en/graphql/reference/unions.intro: A union  is a type of object representing many objects.

/en/graphql/reference/input-objects.title: Input objects
/en/graphql/reference/input-objects.intro: Input objects can be described as "composable objects" because they include a set of input fields that define the object.

/en/graphql/reference/scalars.title: Scalars
/en/graphql/reference/scalars.intro: Scalars are primitive values Int, Float, String, Boolean, or ID.

/en/graphql/guides.title: Guides
/en/graphql/guides.intro: Learn about getting started with GraphQL, migrating from REST to GraphQL, and how to use the GitHub GraphQL API for a variety of tasks.

/en/graphql/guides/introduction-to-graph.title: Introduction to GraphQL
/en/graphql/guides/introduction-to-graph.intro: Learn useful terminology and concepts for using the GitHub GraphQL API.

/en/graphql/guides/forming-calls-with-gr.title: Forming calls with GraphQL
/en/graphql/guides/forming-calls-with-gr.intro: Learn how to authenticate to the GraphQL API, then learn how to create and run queries and mutations.

/en/graphql/guides/using-global-node-ids.title: Using global node IDs
/en/graphql/guides/using-global-node-ids.intro: You can get global node IDs of objects via the REST API and use them in GraphQL operations.

/en/graphql/guides/migrating-from-rest-t.title: Migrating from REST to GraphQL
/en/graphql/guides/migrating-from-rest-t.intro: Learn best practices and considerations for migrating from GitHub's REST API to GitHub's GraphQL API.

/en/graphql/guides/using-the-explorer.title: Using the Explorer
/en/graphql/guides/using-the-explorer.intro: You can run queries on real GitHub data using the GraphQL Explorer, an integrated development environment in your browser that includes docs, syntax highlighting, and validation errors.

/en/graphql/guides/using-pagination-in-t.title: Using pagination in the GraphQL API
/en/graphql/guides/using-pagination-in-t.intro: Learn how to traverse data sets using cursor based pagination with the GraphQL API.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/graphql/guid.title: Managing enterprise accounts
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/graphql/guid.intro: You can manage your enterprise account and the organizations it owns with the GraphQL API.

/en/graphql/guides/using-the-graphql-api.title: Using the GraphQL API for Discussions
/en/graphql/guides/using-the-graphql-api.intro: Learn how to use the GitHub Discussions GraphQL API.

/en/graphql/guides/migrating-graphql-glo.title: Migrating GraphQL global node IDs
/en/graphql/guides/migrating-graphql-glo.intro: Learn about the two global node ID formats and how to migrate from the legacy format to the new format.

/en/github-cli.title: GitHub CLI documentation
/en/github-cli.intro: GitHub CLI is an open source tool for using GitHub from your computer's command line. When you're working from the command line, you can use the GitHub CLI to save time and avoid switching context.

/en/github-cli/github-cli.title: GitHub CLI
/en/github-cli/github-cli.intro: GitHub CLI is an open source tool for using GitHub from your computer's command line. When you're working from the command line, you can use the GitHub CLI to save time and avoid switching context.

/en/github-cli/github-cli/about-github-c.title: About GitHub CLI
/en/github-cli/github-cli/about-github-c.intro: GitHub CLI is a command-line tool that brings pull requests, issues, GitHub Actions, and other GitHub features to your terminal, so you can do all your work in one place.

/en/github-cli/github-cli/quickstart.title: GitHub CLI quickstart
/en/github-cli/github-cli/quickstart.intro: Start using GitHub CLI to work with GitHub in the command line.

/en/github-cli/github-cli/creating-githu.title: Creating GitHub CLI extensions
/en/github-cli/github-cli/creating-githu.intro: Learn how to share new GitHub CLI commands with other users by creating custom extensions for GitHub CLI.

/en/github-cli/github-cli/using-github-c.title: Using GitHub CLI extensions
/en/github-cli/github-cli/using-github-c.intro: Learn how to use custom extensions written by other GitHub CLI users.

/en/github-cli/github-cli/github-cli-ref.title: GitHub CLI reference
/en/github-cli/github-cli/github-cli-ref.intro: You can view all of the GitHub CLI commands in your terminal. The same information is available in the GitHub CLI manual.

/en/discussions.title: GitHub Discussions documentation
/en/discussions.intro: GitHub Discussions is a collaborative communication forum for the community around an open source or internal project. Community members can ask and answer questions, share updates, have open-ended conversations, and follow along on decisions affecting the community's way of working.

/en/discussions/quickstart.title: Quickstart for GitHub Discussions
/en/discussions/quickstart.intro: Enable GitHub Discussions on an existing repository or organization and start conversations with your community.

/en/discussions/guides.title: Discussions guides
/en/discussions/guides.intro: Discover pathways to get started or learn best practices for participating or monitoring your community's discussions.

/en/discussions/guides/best-practices-fo.title: Best practices for community conversations on GitHub
/en/discussions/guides/best-practices-fo.intro: You can use discussions to brainstorm with your team, and eventually move the conversation to an issue when you are ready to scope out the work.

/en/discussions/guides/finding-your-disc.title: Finding your discussions
/en/discussions/guides/finding-your-disc.intro: You can easily access every discussion you've created or participated in.

/en/discussions/guides/granting-higher-p.title: Granting higher permissions to top contributors
/en/discussions/guides/granting-higher-p.intro: Repository administrators can promote any community member to a moderator and maintainer.

/en/discussions/collaborating-with-your-.title: Collaborating with your community using discussions
/en/discussions/collaborating-with-your-.intro: Gather and discuss your project with community members and other maintainers.

/en/discussions/collaborating-with-your-.title: About discussions
/en/discussions/collaborating-with-your-.intro: Use discussions to ask and answer questions, share information, make announcements, and conduct or participate in a conversation about a project on GitHub.

/en/discussions/collaborating-with-your-.title: Participating in a discussion
/en/discussions/collaborating-with-your-.intro: You can converse with the community and maintainers in a forum within the repository for a project on GitHub.

/en/discussions/collaborating-with-your-.title: Collaborating with maintainers using discussions
/en/discussions/collaborating-with-your-.intro: You can contribute to the goals, plans, health, and community for a project on GitHub by communicating with the maintainers of the project in a discussion.

/en/discussions/managing-discussions-for.title: Managing discussions for your community
/en/discussions/managing-discussions-for.intro: You can enable and configure GitHub Discussions for your repository, and you can use tools on GitHub to moderate conversations among community members.

/en/discussions/managing-discussions-for.title: Managing discussions
/en/discussions/managing-discussions-for.intro: You can categorize, spotlight, transfer, or delete the discussions.

/en/discussions/managing-discussions-for.title: Managing categories for discussions
/en/discussions/managing-discussions-for.intro: You can categorize discussions to organize conversations for your community members, and you can choose a format for each category.

/en/discussions/managing-discussions-for.title: Moderating discussions
/en/discussions/managing-discussions-for.intro: You can promote healthy collaboration by marking comments as answers, locking or unlocking discussions, converting issues to discussions, and editing or deleting comments, discussions, and categories that don't align with your community's code of conduct.

/en/discussions/managing-discussions-for.title: Viewing insights for your discussions
/en/discussions/managing-discussions-for.intro: Discussions insights provide data about your discussions' activity, views, and contributors.

/en/discussions/managing-discussions-for.title: Creating discussion category forms
/en/discussions/managing-discussions-for.intro: You can customize the templates that are available for community members to use when they open new discussions in your repository.

/en/discussions/managing-discussions-for.title: Syntax for discussion category forms
/en/discussions/managing-discussions-for.intro: You can use YAML syntax to define the fields in your discussion category forms.

/en/sponsors.title: GitHub Sponsors documentation
/en/sponsors.intro: Invest in the open source projects you depend on, support digital infrastructure, and make open source careers possible by sponsoring open source contributors and their projects. Build a GitHub Sponsors profile and receive compensation for your open source work.

/en/sponsors/getting-started-with-github.title: Getting started with GitHub Sponsors
/en/sponsors/getting-started-with-github.intro: Learn about GitHub Sponsors and how you can get involved as a sponsor or open source contributor.

/en/sponsors/getting-started-with-github.title: About GitHub Sponsors
/en/sponsors/getting-started-with-github.intro: GitHub Sponsors allows the developer community to financially support the people and organizations who design, build, and maintain the open source projects they depend on, directly on GitHub.

/en/sponsors/getting-started-with-github.title: Quickstart for finding contributors to sponsor
/en/sponsors/getting-started-with-github.intro: Learn some best practices for finding open source contributors to sponsor.

/en/sponsors/sponsoring-open-source-cont.title: Sponsoring open source contributors
/en/sponsors/sponsoring-open-source-cont.intro: You can sponsor contributors, receive updates on developers and organizations you sponsor, and display a sponsor badge throughout GitHub.

/en/sponsors/sponsoring-open-source-cont.title: About sponsorships, fees, and taxes
/en/sponsors/sponsoring-open-source-cont.intro: Learn about sponsorships, payment, and tax information for GitHub Sponsors.

/en/sponsors/sponsoring-open-source-cont.title: Sponsoring an open source contributor through GitHub
/en/sponsors/sponsoring-open-source-cont.intro: You can make payments through GitHub to a developer or organization who designs, creates, or maintains open source projects you depend on.

/en/sponsors/sponsoring-open-source-cont.title: Sponsoring an open source contributor through Patreon
/en/sponsors/sponsoring-open-source-cont.intro: You can make payments through Patreon on GitHub.com to a developer or organization who designs, creates, or maintains open source projects you depend on.

/en/sponsors/sponsoring-open-source-cont.title: Managing your sponsorship
/en/sponsors/sponsoring-open-source-cont.intro: You can manage who can see your sponsorship and whether you receive email updates from the sponsored account.

/en/sponsors/sponsoring-open-source-cont.title: Attributing sponsorships to your organization
/en/sponsors/sponsoring-open-source-cont.intro: You can attribute the sponsorships paid by one of your organizations to another organization.

/en/sponsors/sponsoring-open-source-cont.title: Paying for GitHub Sponsors by invoice
/en/sponsors/sponsoring-open-source-cont.intro: Organizations can set up invoicing to sponsor accounts.

/en/sponsors/sponsoring-open-source-cont.title: Unlinking your Patreon account from your GitHub account
/en/sponsors/sponsoring-open-source-cont.intro: You can disconnect your Patreon account from your GitHub account to stop receiving recognition for Patreon sponsorships on GitHub.

/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.title: Receiving sponsorships through GitHub Sponsors
/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.intro: You or your organization can become a sponsored open source contributor to receive payments for your work, update your sponsorship details, and view and contact your sponsors.

/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.title: About GitHub Sponsors for open source contributors
/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.intro: If you provide value to an open source project, you can become a sponsored contributor to receive payments for your work.

/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.title: Setting up GitHub Sponsors for your personal account
/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.intro: You can become a sponsored developer by joining GitHub Sponsors, completing your sponsored developer profile, creating sponsorship tiers, submitting your bank and tax information, and enabling two-factor authentication for your account on GitHub.com.

/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.title: Setting up GitHub Sponsors for your organization
/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.intro: Your organization can join GitHub Sponsors to receive payments for your work.

/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.title: Enabling sponsorships through Patreon
/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.intro: You can connect your Patreon and GitHub accounts to receive GitHub Sponsors sponsorships through Patreon.

/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.title: Using a fiscal host to receive GitHub Sponsors payouts
/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.intro: You can become a sponsored developer by joining GitHub Sponsors and choosing a fiscal host for your payouts to come through.

/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.title: Editing your profile details for GitHub Sponsors
/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.intro: You can update the information that potential sponsors see about your work.

/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.title: Managing your sponsorship goal
/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.intro: You can set a goal for your sponsored developer or sponsored organization account to help the community understand the impact of sponsoring you.

/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.title: Managing your sponsorship tiers
/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.intro: You can add a new sponsorship tier, or edit or retire an existing tier.

/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.title: Viewing your sponsors and sponsorships
/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.intro: You can view and export detailed information and analytics about your sponsors and sponsorships.

/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.title: Managing your payouts from GitHub Sponsors
/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.intro: You can view information about past and future payouts from GitHub Sponsors and edit your bank information.

/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.title: Contacting your sponsors
/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.intro: You can send an email to your sponsors who have opted in to receive updates about your work.

/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.title: Tax information for GitHub Sponsors
/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.intro: Sponsored developers and organizations must submit tax information to GitHub and are responsible for evaluating and paying their own taxes.

/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.title: Unlinking your Patreon account from your GitHub Sponsors profile
/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.intro: You can disconnect your Patreon account from your GitHub Sponsors profile to stop receiving new sponsorships through Patreon.

/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.title: Disabling your GitHub Sponsors account
/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.intro: If you no longer want to participate in GitHub Sponsors, you can disable your GitHub Sponsors account.

/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.title: Unpublishing your GitHub Sponsors profile
/en/sponsors/receiving-sponsorships-thro.intro: If you don't have any sponsors, you can unpublish your GitHub Sponsors profile.

/en/sponsors/integrating-with-github-spo.title: Integrating with GitHub Sponsors
/en/sponsors/integrating-with-github-spo.intro: As an open source contributor, you can build custom tools to manage your GitHub sponsorships.

/en/sponsors/integrating-with-github-spo.title: Configuring webhooks for events in your sponsored account
/en/sponsors/integrating-with-github-spo.intro: You can configure webhooks to alert you when you receive new sponsorships or existing sponsors make changes to their sponsorships.

/en/sponsors/integrating-with-github-spo.title: Getting started with the Sponsors GraphQL API
/en/sponsors/integrating-with-github-spo.intro: Using the GraphQL API, you can build custom integrations to manage or review your sponsorships.

/en/sponsors/guides.title: Guides for GitHub Sponsors
/en/sponsors/guides.intro: Learn how to make the most of GitHub Sponsors.

/en/communities.title: Building communities documentation
/en/communities.intro: Learn best practices for moderating and setting up collaborative, safe, and effective communities using GitHub’s community-tested tools.

/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.title: Setting up your project for healthy contributions
/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.intro: Repository maintainers can set contributing guidelines to help collaborators make meaningful, useful contributions to a project.

/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.title: About community management and moderation
/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.intro: GitHub offers tools that help repository maintainers establish and enforce standards of behavior in their communities on GitHub.com.

/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.title: About community profiles for public repositories
/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.intro: Repository maintainers can review their public repository's community profile to learn how they can help grow their community and support contributors. Contributors can view a public repository's community profile to see if they want to contribute to the project.

/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.title: Accessing a project's community profile
/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.intro: View a public repository's community profile to check on a project's health and decide if you want to contribute.

/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.title: Adding a code of conduct to your project
/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.intro: Adopt a code of conduct to define community standards, signal a welcoming and inclusive project, and outline procedures for handling abuse.

/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.title: Setting guidelines for repository contributors
/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.intro: You can create guidelines to communicate how people should contribute to your project.

/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.title: Adding a license to a repository
/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.intro: You can include an open source license in your repository to make it easier for other people to contribute.

/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.title: Adding support resources to your project
/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.intro: You can create a SUPPORT file to let people know about ways to get help with your project.

/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.title: Creating a default community health file
/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.intro: You can create default community health files, such as CONTRIBUTING and CODE_OF_CONDUCT. Default files will be used for any repository owned by the account that does not contain its own file of that type.

/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.title: Encouraging helpful contributions to your project with labels
/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-.intro: Apply the good first issue label to issues in your repository to highlight opportunities for people to contribute to your project.

/en/communities/using-templates-to-encou.title: Using templates to encourage useful issues and pull requests
/en/communities/using-templates-to-encou.intro: Repository maintainers can add templates in a repository to help contributors create high-quality issues and pull requests.

/en/communities/using-templates-to-encou.title: About issue and pull request templates
/en/communities/using-templates-to-encou.intro: With issue and pull request templates, you can customize and standardize the information you'd like contributors to include when they open issues and pull requests in your repository.

/en/communities/using-templates-to-encou.title: Configuring issue templates for your repository
/en/communities/using-templates-to-encou.intro: You can customize the templates that are available for contributors to use when they open new issues in your repository.

/en/communities/using-templates-to-encou.title: Syntax for issue forms
/en/communities/using-templates-to-encou.intro: You can define different input types, validations, default assignees, and default labels for your issue forms.

/en/communities/using-templates-to-encou.title: Syntax for GitHub's form schema
/en/communities/using-templates-to-encou.intro: You can use GitHub's form schema to configure forms for supported features.

/en/communities/using-templates-to-encou.title: Creating a pull request template for your repository
/en/communities/using-templates-to-encou.intro: When you add a pull request template to your repository, project contributors will automatically see the template's contents in the pull request body.

/en/communities/using-templates-to-encou.title: Manually creating a single issue template for your repository
/en/communities/using-templates-to-encou.intro: When you add a manually-created issue template to your repository, project contributors will automatically see the template's contents in the issue body.

/en/communities/using-templates-to-encou.title: Common validation errors when creating issue forms
/en/communities/using-templates-to-encou.intro: You may see some of these common validation errors when creating, saving, or viewing issue forms.

/en/communities/moderating-comments-and-.title: Moderating comments and conversations
/en/communities/moderating-comments-and-.intro: Moderating conversations creates a welcoming community for all contributors to your project by promoting healthy collaboration and de-escalating conflict. You can apply your community's code of conduct to discussions by viewing reported content, editing and deleting comments, and locking conversations.

/en/communities/moderating-comments-and-.title: Managing disruptive comments
/en/communities/moderating-comments-and-.intro: You can hide, edit, or delete comments on issues, pull requests, and commits.

/en/communities/moderating-comments-and-.title: Locking conversations
/en/communities/moderating-comments-and-.intro: Repository owners and collaborators, and people with write access to a repository, can lock conversations on issues, pull requests, and commits permanently or temporarily to defuse a heated interaction.

/en/communities/moderating-comments-and-.title: Limiting interactions in your repository
/en/communities/moderating-comments-and-.intro: You can temporarily enforce a period of limited activity for certain users on a public repository.
